instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
hi buddy, this mac has no oxidation, just dust.

Voltage:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.60V; <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V; <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V pulses 1.52V when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> quickly; <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> pulses to 1.78V when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.   
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.24V; <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.41V; <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN3</SIGNAL>.21V;<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.3.42V.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
Any pulse at VCORE too?
Also check at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0v no pulse.
missing <SIGNAL>PP3V_S0</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
Do you get pulse on other big coils?
No pulse at all at <SIGNAL>3V_S0</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
L7520 0v
L7430 0V
L7560 3.35V
L7710 0v
L3095 0v
L7130 12.83 / 12.60V
L7320 0V
L7310 0V
L7630 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 0v, there is pulse 1.63V. I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.34V, should I also have <SIGNAL>PP3V_S0</SIGNAL> voltage ?
detail that I forgot to say <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> had oxidation on pins 10 and 9, replace the component by precaution.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
Is strange you mentioned pulse on <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, but nothing on L7520.
Are you sure, or didn't even check L7520 for pulse???
What do you expect to get without 5V on the board?

Try to find a logic in the repair proces.
How can you go for S0 voltages, when no S4/3 present???

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message: L7520 0V, pulse is 2.75V and back 0V.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
Then you should have pulse on more coils.
Why don't you post accurate information???
You've mentioned a pulse on <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, but you do not want to tell us nothing about other power rails.
Do I need to ask you every time for one voltage in particular?

Pins 5/6 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulsing?

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
6 - 3.31V
5 - 0V, there's a 0.09V pulse.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
"6 - 3.31V"
Pulse, or steady voltage???
Try to understand, you are the first interested to post as more as possible and accurate information.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message: yes constant voltage.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
does not accept SMC Bypass, the led erases from the magSafe when you try this method. Could it be an SMC defect ?

Read a post that you indicate to do the Reball SMC, asking to test certain voltages before, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>. In my case the tensions are the same of this member.  
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 54200, member: 682"]
Missing 2 (two) RTC signals, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>.
If good, then reball SMC.
[/QUOTE].

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
Something strange with your measurments; maybe SMC problem.
Pin 6 must rise after pin 5; I talk about <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pins.
Change SMC and try again.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message: I don't want to rush, is there any more tension that I can measure to make sure that a SMC Reballing is needed?

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message: Did you try to start in SMC byapss mode?

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message: Yes, several times, it does not accept the deviation of the SMC. Detail when using this mode, the MagSafe light goes out.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
Magsafe light goes and stays off?
You should try without keyboard connected...

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message: I tried with the keypad disconnected and it's still with the magsafe light off.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
So Magsafe remains off, untill disconnect/reconnect charger?
What happen with <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal?
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> have both correct voltage in that time?

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.39V; <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.29V; <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V; There was a voltage drop in PPBUS.
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 63030, member: 682"]
So Magsafe remains off, untill disconnect/reconnect charger?
[/QUOTE]
Exactly.

Because you posted correct voltage in the previous posts...

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message: a PPBUS is 12.29V when it tries to bypass the SMC, when it is in that state it has this voltage.

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message:
You should reball SMC.
If doesn't help, change it...

threads.title: 820- 4924-a no power, orange light
threads.message: I did the SMC reball, no result. I don't imagine it is the defect in SMC, Do you have any idea which component is causing this defect?
